intro.title: Isn’t the Bible Filled with Contradictions?
intro.description: Some people use a few apparently contradictory stories of the Bible to attack it. However, these people make a superficial and selective reading of the Biblical text. When the Bible is examined within its greater context, its stories are not contradictory, but complementary.

appendix.appendixContent:
Mark 10:46-52

46 Now they came to Jericho. As He went out of Jericho with His disciples and a great multitude, blind Bartimaeus, the son of Timaeus, sat by the road begging.47 And when he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to cry out and say, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”48 Then many warned him to be quiet; but he cried out all the more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”49 So Jesus stood still and commanded him to be called. Then they called the blind man, saying to him, “Be of good cheer. Rise, He is calling you.”50 And throwing aside his garment, he rose and came to Jesus.51 So Jesus answered and said to him, “What do you want Me to do for you?” The blind man said to Him, “Rabboni, that I may receive my sight.”52 Then Jesus said to him, “Go your way; your faith has made you well.” And immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus on the road.

questions.description: Mark 10:46-52 and Matthew 20:29-34 bring a story that we can use as an example. Matthew says that Jesus healed two blind men in the proximities of Jericho and Mark says it was only one. Would this be a contradiction? Not necessarily. What probably happened is that Mark wanted to highlight the experience of one of the blind men and ended up omitting the other one. In order to avoid this feeling of contradiction, the Bible needs to be examined in its context, because its stories are complimentary. Other factors that are beyond what it is written in its pages must be taken into consideration.

appendix.appendixContent:
Luke 18:35-43

35 Then it happened, as He was coming near Jericho, that a certain blind man sat by the road begging.36 And hearing a multitude passing by, he asked what it meant.37 So they told him that Jesus of Nazareth was passing by.38 And he cried out, saying, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”39 Then those who went before warned him that he should be quiet; but he cried out all the more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”40 So Jesus stood still and commanded him to be brought to Him. And when he had come near, He asked him,41 saying, “What do you want Me to do for you?” He said, “Lord, that I may receive my sight.”42 Then Jesus said to him, “Receive your sight; your faith has made you well.”43 And immediately he received his sight, and followed Him, glorifying God. And all the people, when they saw it, gave praise to God.

questions.description: The cultural factor becomes evident when we compare both accounts of Matthew 20:29-34 and Mark 10: 46-52, with the one in Luke 18:35-43 about the same event. Luke says that the healing took place when Jesus was going into the city, while the other Gospel writers say it happened when He left the city. There are a few ways to reconcile these accounts. One of them is considering the cultural fact that there were two cities of Jericho, an old and a new one, which allows for the fact that Jesus could be healing at the entrance of one and, at the same time, at the end of another. As like in the previous example, the Bible is filled with repeated stories. That is, different authors wrote in the same way about the same event. Nowadays we call this plagiarism, which is even considered a crime.

questions.description: The passages of Isaiah 2:2 and Micah 4:2 present the same prophecy with very similar wording. Some Bible critics could accuse these texts of plagiarism, but this is a modern concept of evaluation that cannot be applied to that time. Regardless of the preferred words of one author or another, of their points of view and interpretations, the Bible has a much greater goal behind its writings.

questions.description: It is worth mentioning that the great purpose of the Bible is not to be precise in all details of the account, whether they are literary, scientific or historical. Its goal is to reveal God’s character through Christ (John 5:39) and his offer of salvation (2 Timothy 3:15-17). In this sense the Bible is infallible.
